In July, he had been stripped of power and taken prisoner, though the Italians feigned continued support of the Axis. On 8 September, the Italians formally surrendered,<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but most of Italy not in Allied hands was controlled by German troops and those loyal to Mussolini's (Mussolini had been freed by German paratroopers) new <a href="/wiki/Italian_Social_Republic" title="Italian Social Republic">Italian Social Republic</a>, which in reality consisted of the shrinking zone of German control. The Germans offered staunch resistance, but by 4 June 1944, Rome had fallen.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic" title="Battle of the Atlantic">Battle of the Atlantic</a> took place from 1942 to 1944 and was described as "longest, largest, and most complex naval battle in history".<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Germans hoped to sever the vital supply lines between Britain and America, sinking many tons of shipping with <a href="/wiki/U-boats" class="mw-redirect" title="U-boats">U-boats</a>, German submarines. However, the development of the <a href="/wiki/Destroyer" title="Destroyer">destroyer</a> and aircraft with a longer patrol range were effective at countering the U-boat threat and by December 1943, the Germans had lost the battle.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Operation_Overlord">Operation Overlord</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Operation Overlord"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>On 6 June 1944, the Western Allies finally launched the long-awaited assault on "Fortress Europe" so wanted by Stalin. The offensive, codenamed <a href="/wiki/Operation_Overlord" title="Operation Overlord">Operation Overlord</a>, began the early morning hours of 6 June. The day, known as <a href="/wiki/D-day" class="mw-redirect" title="D-day">D-day</a>, was marked by foul weather.  Rommel, who was now in charge of defending France against possible Allied attack, thought the Allies would not attack during the stormy weather, and was on holiday in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Besides this, the Germans were expecting an attack, but at the natural harbor of <a href="/wiki/Calais" title="Calais">Calais</a> and not the beaches of <a href="/wiki/Normandy" title="Normandy">Normandy</a>; They did not know about the Allies' <a href="/wiki/Mulberry_Harbour" class="mw-redirect" title="Mulberry Harbour">artificial harbours</a>, and false leads planted by the Allies suggested Calais as the landing site.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Approaching_Omaha.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Approaching_Omaha.jpg/250px-Approaching_Omaha.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="179" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Approaching_Omaha.jpg/500px-Approaching_Omaha.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2147"></a><figcaption>U.S. assault troops approaching <a href="/wiki/Omaha_Beach" title="Omaha Beach">Omaha Beach</a>, 6 June 1944.</figcaption></figure>
<p>By this time, the war was looking ever darker for Germany. On 20 July 1944, a group of conspiring German officers attempted to assassinate Hitler. The bomb they used did injure him, but the second was not used, and a table shielded Hitler in a stroke of luck.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The plotters still could have launched a coup, but only the head of occupied Paris acted, arresting <a href="/wiki/SS" class="mw-redirect" title="SS">SS</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gestapo" title="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> forces in the city. The German propaganda minister, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Goebbels" title="Joseph Goebbels">Joseph Goebbels</a>, rallied the Nazis and hunted down the conspirators, arresting up to 7000 people in the wake of the plot, according to some estimates.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In France, the Allies took Normandy and finally Paris on 25 August.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the east, the Soviets had advanced almost to the former Polish-Soviet border. At this time, Hitler introduced the <a href="/wiki/V-weapons" title="V-weapons">V-weapons</a>, the <a href="/wiki/V-1_flying_bomb" title="V-1 flying bomb">V-1 flying bomb</a> and, later, the <a href="/wiki/V-2" class="mw-redirect" title="V-2">V-2</a>, the first rockets used in modern warfare. The V-1 was often intercepted by air pilots, but the V-2 was extremely fast and carried a large payload. However, this advance came too late in the war to have any real effect.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Germans were also on the verge of introducing a number of terrifying new weapons, including advanced jet aircraft, which were too fast for ordinary propeller aircraft, and submarine improvements which would allow the Germans to again fight effectively in the Atlantic. All this came too late to save Hitler. Although a September invasion of The Netherlands failed, the Allies made steady advances. In the winter of 1944, Hitler put everything into one last desperate gamble in the West, known as the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bulge" title="Battle of the Bulge">Battle of the Bulge</a>, which, despite an initial advance, was a failure, because the introduction of new Allied tanks and low troop numbers among the Germans prevented any real action being taken. Nevertheless, it was one of the bloodiest battles of the war and <a href="/wiki/List_of_battles_with_most_United_States_military_fatalities" title="List of battles with most United States military fatalities">the second costliest battle in the history of the American Army</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Final_days">Final days</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Final days"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In early February 1945, the three Allied leaders, <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Delano_Roosevelt" class="mw-redirect" title="Franklin Delano Roosevelt">Franklin Roosevelt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, met at newly liberated <a href="/wiki/Yalta" title="Yalta">Yalta</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Crimean Peninsula">Crimea</a> in the Soviet Union in the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Here, they agreed upon a plan to divide post-war Europe. Most of the east went to Stalin, who agreed to allow free elections in Eastern Europe, which he never did. The west went to Britain, France, and the U.S. Post-war Germany would be split between the four, as would Berlin. This division of spheres of influence would set up international diplomacy for the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> that would dominate the second half of the century.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>At the beginning of 1945, Hitler was on his last strings. The Soviets launched a devastating attack from Poland into Germany and Eastern Europe, intending to take Berlin. The Germans collapsed in the West, allowing the Allies to fan out across Germany. However, the Supreme Allied Commander, American general <a href="/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower" title="Dwight D. Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a>, refused to strike for Berlin, and instead became obsessed with reports of possible guerrilla activity in southern Germany, which in reality existed mainly in the propaganda of Joseph Goebbels.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By 25 April the Soviets had besieged Berlin. Hitler remained in the city in a bunker under the <a href="/wiki/Reich_Chancellery" title="Reich Chancellery">Chancellery</a> garden. On 30 April he committed suicide by shooting himself, after a ritual wedding with his longtime mistress <a href="/wiki/Eva_Braun" title="Eva Braun">Eva Braun</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Germans held out another 7 days under <a href="/wiki/Karl_D%C3%B6nitz" title="Karl Dönitz">Admiral Doenitz</a>, their new leader, but the Germans surrendered unconditionally on 7 May 1945, ending the war in Europe (see <a href="/wiki/V-E_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="V-E Day">V-E Day</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Rivalries that had begun during the war, combined with the sense of strength in the victorious powers, laid the foundations of the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> and of the Cold War.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_war_in_the_Pacific">The war in the Pacific</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: The war in the Pacific"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Asiatic-Pacific_Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Asiatic-Pacific Theater">Asiatic-Pacific Theater</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Background">Background</h5><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Background"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The first event that is usually linked to the later Pacific conflict was the <a href="/wiki/Mukden_Incident" class="mw-redirect" title="Mukden Incident">Mukden Incident</a> of 18 September 1931, during which the Japanese military staged the bombing of the <a href="/wiki/South_Manchuria_Railway" title="South Manchuria Railway">South Manchuria Railway</a> and pinned the blame on Chinese dissidents.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan then used this as <a href="/wiki/Casus_belli" title="Casus belli">pretext</a> to <a href="/wiki/Japanese_invasion_of_Manchuria" title="Japanese invasion of Manchuria">invade northeastern China</a> the next day and turn the region of <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a> into the Japanese <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a> of <a href="/wiki/Manchukuo" title="Manchukuo">Manchukuo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After the League of Nations commissioned the 1932 <a href="/wiki/Lytton_Report" title="Lytton Report">Lytton Report</a>, which exposed the Mukden Incident as a Japanese ruse, Japan was left internationally isolated, withdrawing from the League of Nations in March 1933. In 1934 Manchukuo became a constitutional monarchy and the former Chinese Emperor <a href="/wiki/Puyi" title="Puyi">Pu Yi</a> was placed on the throne, despite the real power being held by Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Despite relations between Japan and China suffering because the occupation of Manchuria, the situation did not turn into all-out war until 7 July 1937, when a dispute between Chinese and Japanese soldiers turned into a battle during the <a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_Bridge_Incident" class="mw-redirect" title="Marco Polo Bridge Incident">Marco Polo Bridge Incident</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This, in turn, led to a further escalation of the hostilities, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a>, one of the deadliest conflicts in human history.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Japan enjoyed some early major victories, capturing both <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Shanghai" title="Battle of Shanghai">Shanghai</a> and the Chinese capital of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nanjing" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Nanjing">Nanjing</a> in 1937 and forcing the Chinese central government 's relocation to <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>. Following Chinese victories in <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Changsha_(1939)" title="Battle of Changsha (1939)">Changsha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_South_Guangxi" title="Battle of South Guangxi">Guangxi</a> in 1939, the war reached somewhat of a stalemate, with Japan controlling the large cities, but being unable to rule the vast countryside.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 27 September 1940, Japan became cosignatories of the <a href="/wiki/Tripartite_Pact" title="Tripartite Pact">Tripartite Pact</a>, joining a military alliance with Germany and Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Japanese_Expansion">Japanese Expansion</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Japanese Expansion"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:USS_West_Virginia2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/USS_West_Virginia2.jpg/250px-USS_West_Virginia2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="200" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/USS_West_Virginia2.jpg/500px-USS_West_Virginia2.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4560" data-file-height="3654"></a><figcaption>USS <i>West Virginia</i> during the attack on Pearl Harbor</figcaption></figure>
<p>On 7 December 1941, Japan launched a surprise attack on the American base at <a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor" title="Pearl Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> as a mean of preventing the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Pacific_Fleet" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Pacific Fleet">U.S. Pacific Fleet</a> from interfering with its planned expansion in the area.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The next day, following Roosevelt's <a href="/wiki/Infamy_Speech" class="mw-redirect" title="Infamy Speech">Infamy Speech</a>, the United States declared war on Japan, marking the official entry of both nations in World War 2.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At the same time, Japan also launched attacks on <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a>, the British colonies of <a href="/wiki/British_Malaya" title="British Malaya">Malaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and American military bases in <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">Guam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wake_Island" title="Wake Island">Wake Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">the Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The next six months were dominated by Japanese victories against the Allied forces, already war-weary and stretched thin after two years of war in Europe and North Africa. Japan managed to capture <a href="/wiki/British_Burma" class="mw-redirect" title="British Burma">British Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea" title="New Guinea">New Guinea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_Indies" title="Dutch East Indies">Dutch East Indies</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands" title="Solomon Islands">Solomon Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timor" title="Timor">Timor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March 1942, days before the surrender of the Philippines, general Douglas MacArthur, who came out of retirement to become commander of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Forces_in_the_Far_East" title="United States Army Forces in the Far East">United States Army Forces in the Far East</a> at the onset of the war, <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur%27s_escape_from_the_Philippines" title="Douglas MacArthur's escape from the Philippines">was forced to flee and narrowly escape</a> to Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 19 February 1942, Japan also launched a devastating aerial attack on the Australian city of Darwin, in what was the first attack by a foreign power on Australian soil.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The turning of the tide came in early May, during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea" title="Battle of the Coral Sea">Battle of the Coral Sea</a>, which proved the first strategic victory of the Allies against Japanese expansion.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was followed one month later by the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Midway" title="Battle of Midway">Battle of Midway</a>, in which the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">US Navy</a> defeated an attacking Japanese fleet, inflicting devastating damage on the attacking force. The Battle of Midway is widely considered the most important naval battle of the Pacific Campaign and has even been described as "the most stunning and decisive blow in the history of naval warfare"<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The reasons usually given for the resounding victory are Japanese overconfidence in their own forces, poor planning and the intercepting of Japanese battle plans by the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The losses suffered during this Battle of Midway, paired with the campaign of attrition that was taking place in <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands_campaign" title="Solomon Islands campaign">Solomon Islands</a>, left Japan unable to replenish its forces and turned the tides of war against it. By August 1942, the Allied forces were on the offensive, earning victories in the <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea_campaign" title="New Guinea campaign">New Guinea campaign</a> at <a href="/wiki/Guadalcanal_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Guadalcanal Campaign">Guadalcanal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Milne_Bay" title="Battle of Milne Bay">Milne Bay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Buna%E2%80%93Gona" title="Battle of Buna–Gona">Buna-Gona</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Allied_offensive">Allied offensive</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Allied offensive"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png/250px-Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="192" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png/500px-Second_world_war_asia_1937-1942_map_en6.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1298" data-file-height="998"></a><figcaption>A map of the Japanese advance from 1937 to 1942</figcaption></figure>
<p>Over the next two years the Allies slowly captured one island base after another, trying to get closer to Japan itself, where it planned to launch massive strategic air attacks and, only if absolutely necessary, execute a ground invasion. By July 1944, the US <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Guam_(1944)" title="Battle of Guam (1944)">recaptured Guam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tinian" title="Battle of Tinian">captured Tinian</a>, which finally put them in attacking range of mainland Japan using the new <a href="/wiki/Boeing_B-29_Superfortress" title="Boeing B-29 Superfortress">Boeing B-29</a> bombers.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite the advances of the Allies, massive fighting was still taking place, both in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">South-East Asia</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Burma_Campaign_1944" class="mw-redirect" title="Burma Campaign 1944">Japanese offensive in India</a> and in the Pacific, with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Philippine_Sea" title="Battle of the Philippine Sea">Battle of the Philippine Sea</a>, where Japan suffered major losses and definitively lost the ability to rely on <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">aircraft carriers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In later October, a combined attack of American and Australian forces took on the Imperial Japanese Navy during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Leyte_Gulf" title="Battle of Leyte Gulf">Battle of Leyte Gulf</a> in what was to be the largest naval battle of World War II and possibly the <a href="/wiki/Largest_naval_battle_in_history" title="Largest naval battle in history">largest naval battle of all time</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Allied victory achieved its stated goal of further severing oil supplied to the Japanese army, which was already struggling to fuel the remainder of its naval power.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The battle of Leyte Gulf is also notable as the first battle in which Japanese aircraft carried out organized <i><a href="/wiki/Kamikaze" title="Kamikaze">kamikaze</a></i> attacks.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>By early 1945, the Americans set their eyes on the Japanese island of Iwo Jima, which was of great strategic importance, being situated halfway between <a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Islands" title="Mariana Islands">Mariana Islands</a>. Capturing the island meant not only a better launch station for aerial attacks against mainland Japan, but also the prevention of its use as an early-warning station against air raids. The Japanese were expecting an attack and have been heavily fortifying the entire island for over a year.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite the American troops outnumbering the Japanese to a rate of more than 3 to 1, the USA suffered heavy casualties in the 36 days of fighting, with over 6,800 Marines killed and another 20,000 wounded,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> leading some historians to question the strategic worth of the action.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> With Japan struggling to defend the homeland islands, counteroffensives in other parts of the Japanese Empire became more feasible, with important battles taking place in <a href="/wiki/Burma_Campaign_1944%E2%80%9345" class="mw-redirect" title="Burma Campaign 1944–45">Burma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borneo_campaign_(1945)" class="mw-redirect" title="Borneo campaign (1945)">Borneo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Second_Guangxi_Campaign" class="mw-redirect" title="Second Guangxi Campaign">China</a>.
</p><p>Continuing to come nearer the main Japanese islands, on 1 April 1945 the US Marines mounted the largest <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_assault" class="mw-redirect" title="Amphibious assault">amphibious assault</a> of the Pacific Theater on the island of <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Okinawa" title="Battle of Okinawa">Okinawa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> After a long campaign of <a href="/wiki/Leapfrogging_(military)" class="mw-redirect" title="Leapfrogging (military)">island hopping</a>, the Allies were planning to use <a href="/wiki/Kadena_Air_Base" title="Kadena Air Base">Kadena Air Base</a> on the large island of Okinawa as a base for <a href="/wiki/Operation_Downfall" title="Operation Downfall">Operation Downfall</a>, the planned invasion of the <a href="/wiki/Japanese_home_islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Japanese home islands">Japanese home islands</a> which were only 340 miles away.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The battle was one of the bloodiest in the Pacific, with approximately 160,000 casualties on both sides: at least 75,000 Allied and 84,166–117,000 Japanese. Around half of the island's population of 300,000 were killed, committed suicide or went missing.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:B-29_Enola_Gay_w_Crews.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/B-29_Enola_Gay_w_Crews.jpg/250px-B-29_Enola_Gay_w_Crews.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/B-29_Enola_Gay_w_Crews.jpg/500px-B-29_Enola_Gay_w_Crews.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="960"></a><figcaption>Enola Gay's ground crew with mission commander <a href="/wiki/Paul_Tibbets" title="Paul Tibbets">Paul Tibbets</a> in the center.</figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Final_days_2">Final days</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Final days"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The assaults on both Iwo Jima and Okinawa proved incredibly costly in terms of American lives and president Truman was horrified at the prospect of Operation Downfall, a planned boots-on-the-ground invasion of mainland Japan that was estimated to lead to over a million casualties among American soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite a devastating campaign of fire-bombing in Tokyo and dozens of other cities, the Japanese showed no sign of planning to surrender. Following the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration" title="Potsdam Declaration">Potsdam Declaration</a> of 26 July, where the Allies threatened "prompt and utter destruction" should Japan not surrender,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the decision was made to resort to the first use of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">atomic bombs</a>. On 6 August, the 393d Bombardment Squadron B-29 <i><a href="/wiki/Enola_Gay" title="Enola Gay">Enola Gay</a></i>, took off from Tinian and dropped the bomb on the city of Hiroshima. Three days later, a second bomb was dropped on Nagasaki. The two bombings killed 129,000–226,000 people, most of them civilians.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 9 August, the Soviet Union also invaded Manchukuo in what was to be the last campaign of the war.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On 10 August the "sacred decision" was made by Japanese Cabinet to accept the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Declaration" title="Potsdam Declaration">Potsdam terms</a> and on 15 August <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Hirohito" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Hirohito">Emperor Hirohito</a> broadcast to the nation and to the world at large the rescript of surrender, ending the Second World War.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The formal <a href="/wiki/Japanese_Instrument_of_Surrender" title="Japanese Instrument of Surrender">Japanese Instrument of Surrender</a> was signed on 2 September 1945, on the battleship <a href="/wiki/USS_Missouri_(BB-63)" title="USS Missouri (BB-63)">USS <i>Missouri</i></a>, in <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Bay" title="Tokyo Bay">Tokyo Bay</a>. The surrender was accepted by General Douglas MacArthur as <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander_of_the_Allied_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers">Supreme Commander of the Allied Powers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_Holocaust">The Holocaust</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: The Holocaust"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust" title="The Holocaust">The Holocaust</a></div>
<p>The Holocaust (which roughly means "great fire") was the deliberate, systematic murder of millions of Jews and other minorities during World War II by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Hitler's Nazi regime</a> in Europe. Several differing views exist regarding whether it was intended to occur from the war's beginning, or if the plans for it came about later.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Regardless, persecution of Jews extended well before the war even started, such as in the <i><a href="/wiki/Kristallnacht" title="Kristallnacht">Kristallnacht</a></i> (literally "Crystal Night", Night of Broken Glass).<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/The_Nazis" class="mw-redirect" title="The Nazis">The Nazis</a> used propaganda to great effect to stir up antisemitic feelings within ordinary Germans. Many people, including politicians and historians, consider the Holocaust to be the worst event in history, and have described Hitler, <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Party" title="Nazi Party">his followers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">his regime</a> as <a href="/wiki/Evil" title="Evil">evil</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg/250px-Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="162" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg/330px-Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg/500px-Buchenwald_Slave_Laborers_Liberation.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2699" data-file-height="2190"></a><figcaption>Slave laborers at the <a href="/wiki/Buchenwald_concentration_camp" title="Buchenwald concentration camp">Buchenwald concentration camp</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After the conquest of Poland, the <a href="/wiki/Third_Reich" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Reich">Third Reich</a>, which had previously deported Jews and other "undesirables", suddenly had within its borders the largest concentration of Jews in the world. The solution was to round up Jews and place them in <a href="/wiki/Nazi_concentration_camps" title="Nazi concentration camps">Nazi concentration camps</a> or in <a href="/wiki/Ghetto" title="Ghetto">ghettos</a>, cordoned off sections of cities where Jews were forced to live in deplorable conditions, often with tens of thousands starving to death, and the bodies decaying in the streets.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As appalling as this sounds, they were the lucky ones. After the invasion of the Soviet Union, armed killing squads of <a href="/wiki/SS" class="mw-redirect" title="SS">SS</a> men known as <i><a href="/wiki/Einsatzgruppen" title="Einsatzgruppen">Einsatzgruppen</a></i> systematically rounded up Jews and murdered an estimated one million Jews within the country.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As barbaric and inhuman as this seems, it was too slow and inefficient by Nazi standards.
</p><p>In 1942, the top leadership met in <a href="/wiki/Wannsee" title="Wannsee">Wannsee</a>, a suburb of Berlin, and began to plan a more efficient way to slaughter the Jews.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Nazis created a system of <a href="/wiki/Extermination_camp" title="Extermination camp">extermination camps</a> throughout Poland, and began rounding up Jews from the Soviet Union, and from the Ghettos.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Not only were Jews shot or gassed to death en masse, but they were forced to provide slave labor and they were used in horrific medical experiments (see <a href="/wiki/Human_experimentation_in_Nazi_Germany" class="mw-redirect" title="Human experimentation in Nazi Germany">Human experimentation in Nazi Germany</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Out of the widespread condemnation of the Nazis' medical experiments, the <a href="/wiki/Nuremberg_Code" title="Nuremberg Code">Nuremberg Code</a> of medical ethics was devised.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Nazis took a sadistic pleasure in the death camps; the entrance to the most notorious camp, <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect" title="Auschwitz">Auschwitz</a>, stated <i>"Arbeit Macht Frei"</i>—"Work Sets You Free".<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the end, six million Jews and up to 5 million homosexuals, <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witness" class="mw-redirect" title="Jehovah's Witness">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a> and political prisoners were killed by various means, mainly in the death camps.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An additional several million Soviet and other Allied prisoners of war died in camps and holding areas.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>There is some controversy over whether ordinary Germans knew about the Holocaust.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It appears that many Germans knew about the concentration camps; such things were prominently displayed in magazines and newspapers.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In many places, Jews had to walk past towns and villages on their way to work as slaves in German industry. In any case, Allied soldiers reported that the smell of the camps carried for miles.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A very small number of people <a href="/wiki/Holocaust_denial" title="Holocaust denial">deny the Holocaust occurred</a> entirely, though these claims have been routinely discredited by mainstream historians.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_Nuclear_Age_begins">The Nuclear Age begins</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: The Nuclear Age begins"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_nuclear_weapons" title="History of nuclear weapons">History of nuclear weapons</a></div>
<p>During the 1930s, innovations in <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</a> made it apparent that it could be possible to develop <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons</a> of incredible power using <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactions" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear reactions">nuclear reactions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When World War II broke out, scientists and advisors among the Allies feared that Nazi Germany may have been trying to develop its own atomic weapons, and the United States and the United Kingdom pooled their efforts in what became known as the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">Manhattan Project</a> to beat them to it. At the secret <a href="/wiki/Los_Alamos_National_Laboratory" title="Los Alamos National Laboratory">Los Alamos laboratory</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">New Mexico</a>, scientist <a href="/wiki/Robert_Oppenheimer" class="mw-redirect" title="Robert Oppenheimer">Robert Oppenheimer</a> led a team of the world's top scientists to develop the first nuclear weapons, the first of which was tested at the <a href="/wiki/Trinity_site" class="mw-redirect" title="Trinity site">Trinity site</a> in July 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, Germany had surrendered in May 1945, and it had been discovered that the <a href="/wiki/German_nuclear_energy_project" class="mw-redirect" title="German nuclear energy project">German atomic bomb program</a> had not been very close to success.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Trinity_Test_Fireball_16ms.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Trinity_Test_Fireball_16ms.jpg/250px-Trinity_Test_Fireball_16ms.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="169" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Trinity_Test_Fireball_16ms.jpg/500px-Trinity_Test_Fireball_16ms.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1483" data-file-height="1000"></a><figcaption>The first <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_explosion" title="Nuclear explosion">nuclear explosion</a>, named "<a href="/wiki/Trinity_site" class="mw-redirect" title="Trinity site">Trinity</a>", was detonated on 16 July 1945.</figcaption></figure><p>The Allied team produced two nuclear weapons for use in the war, one powered by <a href="/wiki/Uranium-235" title="Uranium-235">uranium-235</a> and the other by <a href="/wiki/Plutonium" title="Plutonium">plutonium</a> as <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">fissionable</a> material, named "<a href="/wiki/Little_Boy" title="Little Boy">Little Boy</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Fat_Man" title="Fat Man">Fat Man</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These were dropped on the Japanese cities of <a href="/wiki/Hiroshima" title="Hiroshima">Hiroshima</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nagasaki" title="Nagasaki">Nagasaki</a> on 6 and 9 August 1945 each. This, in combination with the Soviet invasion of Japanese-controlled territory, convinced the Japanese government to surrender unconditionally. These two weapons remain the only two nuclear weapons ever used against other countries in war.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Nuclear weapons brought an entirely new and <a href="/wiki/Damocles" class="mw-redirect" title="Damocles">terrifying possibility</a> to <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">warfare</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_holocaust" title="Nuclear holocaust">nuclear annihilation</a>, because it was feared that they would bring about the <a href="/wiki/Human_extinction" title="Human extinction">human extinction</a> overnight. While at first the United States held a monopoly on the production of nuclear weapons, the Soviet Union, with some assistance from espionage, managed to detonate its first weapon (dubbed "<a href="/wiki/Joe-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Joe-1">Joe-1</a>" by the West) in August 1949.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The post-war relations between the two, which had already been deteriorating, began to rapidly disintegrate. Soon the two were locked in a massive stockpiling of nuclear weapons. The United States began a crash program to develop the first <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_bomb" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydrogen bomb">hydrogen bomb</a> in 1950, and detonated its first <a href="/wiki/Thermonuclear" class="mw-redirect" title="Thermonuclear">thermonuclear</a> weapon in 1952. This new weapon was alone over 400 times as powerful as the weapons used against Japan. The Soviet Union detonated a primitive thermonuclear weapon in 1953 and a full-fledged one in 1955.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Trident_II_missile_image.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/250px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="241" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/330px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/500px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2486" data-file-height="3000"></a><figcaption>Nuclear missiles and computerized launch systems increased the range and scope of possible <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">nuclear war</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The conflict continued to escalate, with the major superpowers developing long-range missiles (such as the <a href="/wiki/ICBM" class="mw-redirect" title="ICBM">ICBM</a>) and a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_strategy" title="Nuclear strategy">nuclear strategy</a> which guaranteed that any use of the nuclear weapons would be suicide for the attacking nation (<a href="/wiki/Mutually_Assured_Destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutually Assured Destruction">Mutually Assured Destruction</a>). The creation of <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_Missile_Early_Warning_System" title="Ballistic Missile Early Warning System">early warning systems</a> put the control of these weapons into the hands of newly created computers, and they served as a tense backdrop throughout the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since the 1940s there were concerns about the rising <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">proliferation of nuclear weapons</a> to new countries, which was seen as being destabilizing to international relations, spurring regional <a href="/wiki/Arms_race" title="Arms race">arms races</a>, and generally increasing the likelihood of some form of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">nuclear war</a>. Eventually, nine nations would overtly develop nuclear weapons, and still maintain stockpiles today: the <a href="/wiki/The_United_States_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="The United States and weapons of mass destruction">United States</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">Soviet Union</a> (and later Russia would inherit these), the <a href="/wiki/The_United_Kingdom_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="The United Kingdom and weapons of mass destruction">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/France_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="France and weapons of mass destruction">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic of China and weapons of mass destruction">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/India_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="India and weapons of mass destruction">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pakistan_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Pakistan and weapons of mass destruction">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/South_Africa_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="South Africa and weapons of mass destruction">South Africa</a> developed six crude weapons in the 1980s (which it later dismantled),<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Israel_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Israel and weapons of mass destruction">Israel</a> almost certainly developed nuclear weapons though it never confirmed nor denied it.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The creation of the <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty">Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty</a> in 1968 was an attempt to curtail such proliferation,<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but a number of countries developed nuclear weapons since it was signed (and many did not sign it), and several other countries, including <a href="/wiki/Libya_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Libya and weapons of mass destruction">Libya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iran_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Iran and weapons of mass destruction">Iran</a> were suspected of having clandestine nuclear weapons programs.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="The_post-war_world">The post-war world</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: The post-war world"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion" title="Post–World War II economic expansion">Post–World War II economic expansion</a></div>
<p>Following World War II, the majority of the industrialized world lay in ruins as a result of aerial bombings, naval bombardment, and protracted land campaigns. The United States was a notable exception to this; barring <a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor" title="Pearl Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> and some minor incidents, the U.S. had suffered no attacks upon its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The United States and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, which, despite the devastation of its most populated areas, rebuilt quickly, found themselves the world's two dominant superpowers.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Much of Western Europe was rebuilt after the war with assistance from the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a>. Germany, chief instigator of the war, was placed under joint military <a href="/wiki/Military_occupation" title="Military occupation">occupation</a> by the United States, Great Britain, France, and the Soviet Union. Berlin, although in Soviet-controlled territory, was also divided among the four powers.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Occupation of Berlin would continue until 1990. Japan was also placed under U.S. occupation, that would last seven years, until 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Oddly, these two <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis</a> powers, despite military occupation, soon rose to become the second (Japan) and third (West Germany) most powerful economies in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following the end of the war, the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> famously prosecuted numerous German officials for <a href="/wiki/War_crime" title="War crime">war crimes</a> and other offenses in the <a href="/wiki/Nuremberg_Trials" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuremberg Trials">Nuremberg Trials</a>. Although <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a> had committed suicide, many of his cronies, including <a href="/wiki/Hermann_G%C3%B6ring" title="Hermann Göring">Hermann Göring</a>, were convicted. Less well-known trials of other <a href="/wiki/Axis_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Axis Powers">Axis</a> officials also occurred, including the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_War_Crime_Trial" class="mw-redirect" title="Tokyo War Crime Trial">Tokyo War Crime Trial</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The failure of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> to prevent World War II essentially discredited the organization, and it was dissolved.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A new attempt at <a href="/wiki/World_peace" title="World peace">world peace</a> was begun with the founding of the United Nations on 24 October 1945, in San Francisco.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Today, nearly all countries are members, but despite its many successes, the organization's success at achieving its goal of world peace is disputed. The organization was never given enough power to overcome the conflicting interests and priorities of its member nations.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_end_of_empires:_decolonization">The end of empires: decolonization</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: The end of empires: decolonization"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Somare,_Michael_(2008).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Somare%2C_Michael_%282008%29.jpg/250px-Somare%2C_Michael_%282008%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="352" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Somare%2C_Michael_%282008%29.jpg/375px-Somare%2C_Michael_%282008%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Somare%2C_Michael_%282008%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="463" data-file-height="652"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Michael_Somare" title="Michael Somare">Michael Somare</a>, the first leader of an independent <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Decolonization" title="Decolonization">Decolonization</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_Imperialism" title="New Imperialism">New Imperialism</a></div>
<p>Almost all the major nations involved in World War II began shedding their overseas colonies soon after the conflict. The tactics employed by the revolutionaries ranged from <a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">non-violent</a> forms of protest to armed rebellions, depending on the nation involved.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Immediately after the war, European powers began a decades-long process of withdrawing from their possessions in Africa and Asia.
</p><p>In India, <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> became a global icon for his non-violent struggle to achieve <a href="/wiki/Indian_independence_movement" title="Indian independence movement">Indian independence</a> whereas <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_Jinnah" title="Muhammad Ali Jinnah">Mohamed Ali Jinnah</a> advocated for the independence of a separate state for Muslims. This was achieved in 1947 with the end of British rule in India and the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition</a> of the territory into modern-day India and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, which would later also further divide, leading to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/People%E2%80%99s_Republic_of_Bangladesh" class="mw-redirect" title="People’s Republic of Bangladesh">People's Republic of Bangladesh</a> in 1971.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Elsewhere in Asia, The United States granted independence to the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>, its major Pacific possession in 1946.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/French_Indochina" title="French Indochina">French Indochina</a>, armed insurrections forced the French out in the early 1950s, leading to the formation of <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In Africa, nationalists such as <a href="/wiki/Jomo_Kenyatta" title="Jomo Kenyatta">Jomo Kenyatta</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah" title="Kwame Nkrumah">Kwame Nkrumah</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a> led their respective nations to independence from foreign rule.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Mere decades before, the British Empire controlled almost half of the continent, but by 1968, the only British possession in Africa was Seychelles (which would also become independent in 1976). Between 1956 and 1962, almost 20 African countries achieved their independence from France.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Through the efforts of <a href="/wiki/Am%C3%ADlcar_Cabral" title="Amílcar Cabral">Amílcar Cabral</a> and others, the Portuguese colonies of <a href="/wiki/Guinea-Bissau" title="Guinea-Bissau">Guinea-Bissau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cape_Verde" title="Cape Verde">Cape Verde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">Angola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mozambique" title="Mozambique">Mozambique</a> and <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe" title="São Tomé and Príncipe">São Tomé and Príncipe</a> followed suit and achieved independence during the mid-1970s, in what was to be the last important wave of African decolonization.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 1946, there were 35 member states in the United Nations, but as the newly independent nations joined the organization, by 1970 membership increased to 127.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The emergence of newly independent countries in Africa and Asia that used the borders of the imperial partitions later led to further conflict.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In many cases this meant that historically antagonistic ethnic or religious groups now needed to share the same country or that several nations held territorial claims over regions which were more or less arbitrarily divided by European powers.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some conflicts which aroused from these tensions, especially the <a href="/wiki/Nigerian_Civil_War" title="Nigerian Civil War">Nigerian Civil War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Congo_War" title="Second Congo War">Second Congo War</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Sudanese_Civil_War" title="Second Sudanese Civil War">Second Sudanese Civil War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War" title="Bangladesh Liberation War">Bangladesh Liberation War</a> have been among the bloodiest wars of the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_Cold_War_(1947–1991)"><span id="The_Cold_War_.281947.E2.80.931991.29"></span>The Cold War (1947–1991)</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: The Cold War (1947–1991)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg/250px-EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="425" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg/375px-EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg/500px-EasternBloc_BorderChange38-48.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="680"></a><figcaption>Post-war territorial changes in Europe and the formation of the Eastern Bloc</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mutual_assured_destruction" title="Mutual assured destruction">Mutual assured destruction</a></div><p>During the Yalta Conference, where the Western, <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalist</a> powers, and the <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">communist</a> Soviet Union agreed on separate spheres of influence in Europe, they set up the stage for a geopolitical rivalry that would dominate international relations for the next five decades.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In March 1946, Winston Churchill gave a now famous speech while visiting <a href="/wiki/Westminster_College_(Missouri)" title="Westminster College (Missouri)">Westminster College</a> in the US which is usually credited as the first use of the term <a href="/wiki/Iron_Curtain" title="Iron Curtain">Iron Curtain</a> to refer to the separation of Soviet and Western areas of influence in Europe:<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><blockquote><p>From <a href="/wiki/Szczecin" title="Szczecin">Stettin</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic</a> to <a href="/wiki/Trieste" title="Trieste">Trieste</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic</a> an iron curtain has descended across the Continent. Behind that line lie all the capitals of the ancient states of Central and Eastern Europe. Warsaw, Berlin, Prague, Vienna, Budapest, Belgrade, Bucharest and Sofia; all these famous cities and the populations around them lie in what I must call the Soviet sphere, and all are subject, in one form or another, not only to Soviet influence but to a very high and in some cases increasing measure of control from Moscow.</p></blockquote><p>Indeed, the Soviet Union had already annexed several countries as <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Republics of the Soviet Union">Soviet Socialist Republics</a> during the war. Eastern <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (<a href="/wiki/Territories_of_Poland_annexed_by_the_Soviet_Union" title="Territories of Poland annexed by the Soviet Union">incorporated</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Byelorussian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic">Byelorussian SSR</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic">Ukrainian SSR</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a> (which became the <a href="/wiki/Latvian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Latvian Soviet Socialist Republic">Latvian SSR</a>), <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a> (which became the <a href="/wiki/Estonian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic">Estonian SSR</a>), <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> ( which became the <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic">Lithuanian SSR</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> part of eastern <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a> (which became the <a href="/wiki/Karelo-Finnish_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic">Karelo-Finnish SSR</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and eastern <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> (part of which became the <a href="/wiki/Moldavian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic" title="Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic">Moldavian SSR</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> were now wholly part of Soviet Union. Furthermore, between 1945 and 1949, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Socialist_Republic_of_Albania" title="People's Socialist Republic of Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_Bulgaria" title="People's Republic of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_People%27s_Republic" title="Polish People's Republic">Poland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Romania" title="Socialist Republic of Romania">Romania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovak_Socialist_Republic" title="Czechoslovak Socialist Republic">Czechoslovakia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_People%27s_Republic" title="Hungarian People's Republic">Hungary</a> and <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> saw communist regimes coming to power and their transformation into <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="People's Republic">People's Republics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While they remained independent countries and their relation with the Soviet authorities would fluctuate over the next half century, they were widely seen as Soviet <a href="/wiki/Satellite_state" title="Satellite state">satellite states</a>. Outside of Europe, countries that would see the rise of communism and would ally themselves to the communist bloc include <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_People%27s_Republic" title="Mongolian People's Republic">Mongolia</a>, China, <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The spread of the communist ideology in general and the Soviet influence in particular made Western leaders nervous and it even lead to Churchill considering a preemptive attack on the USSR even before World War II was formally ended.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The two rival blocks also coalesced into formal mutual defense organizations, with the formation of the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization_(NATO)" class="mw-redirect" title="North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)">North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)</a> in 1949<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> in 1955,<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> each determine to expand its own influence among <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">unaligned countries</a> and limit the influence of their rivals.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="War_by_proxy">War by proxy</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: War by proxy"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a></div>
<p>Two wars and a near-war in the 1950s became the focus for capitalist versus communist struggle. The first war was the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, fought between People's Republic of China-backed <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> and mainly United States-backed <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>. The Korean Peninsula was a Japanese colony between 1910 and 1945, when Soviet and American troops invaded and divided it along the <a href="/wiki/38th_parallel_north" class="mw-redirect" title="38th parallel north">38th parallel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A communist government controlled the territory north of the border and a capitalist one controlled the South, with both authorities considering the other one illegitimate and claiming sovereignty over the entire peninsula.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> North Korea's invasion of South Korea on 25 June 1950 led to United Nations intervention.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> General <a href="/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur" title="Douglas MacArthur">Douglas MacArthur</a> led troops from the United States, Canada, Australia, Great Britain, and other countries in repulsing the Northern invasion. However, the war reached a stalemate after Chinese intervention pushed U.N. forces back, and an <a href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Korean_Armistice_Agreement" class="extiw" title="s:Korean Armistice Agreement">Armistice</a> ended hostilities in July 1953, leaving the two Koreas divided and tense for the rest of the century.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The second war, the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, was perhaps the third most visible war of the 20th century, after World War I and World War II. After the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dien_Bien_Phu" title="Battle of Dien Bien Phu">French withdrawal</a> from its former colony, on 21 July 1954, Vietnam became partitioned into two halves, much like Korea, along the <a href="/wiki/17th_parallel_north" class="mw-redirect" title="17th parallel north">17th parallel</a>. Fighting between North and South eventually escalated into a regional war. The United States provided aid to South Vietnam<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and contributed to propaganda efforts against the North,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but was not directly involved until the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin_Resolution" title="Gulf of Tonkin Resolution">Gulf of Tonkin Resolution</a>, passed in reaction to a supposed North Vietnamese attack upon American <a href="/wiki/Destroyer" title="Destroyer">destroyers</a>, brought the U.S. into the war as a belligerent.<sup id="cite_ref-204"
