class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The war was initially viewed as a fight to contain communism (see <a href="/wiki/Containment" title="Containment">containment</a>, <a href="/wiki/Truman_Doctrine" title="Truman Doctrine">Truman Doctrine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Domino_Theory" class="mw-redirect" title="Domino Theory">Domino Theory</a>), but, as more Americans were <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">drafted</a> and news of events such as the <a href="/wiki/Tet_Offensive" title="Tet Offensive">Tet Offensive</a> and <a href="/wiki/My_Lai_massacre" title="My Lai massacre">My Lai massacre</a> leaked out, American sentiment turned against the war.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> was elected partially on a promise to end the war. This <a href="/wiki/Nixon_Doctrine" title="Nixon Doctrine">Nixon Doctrine</a> involved a gradual pullout of American forces; South Vietnamese units were supposed to replace them, backed up by American air power. The plan went awry, with Nixon  deliberately sabotaging peace talks for political gain,<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the war spilled into neighboring <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a> while South Vietnamese forces were pushed further back.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Eventually, the U.S. and North Vietnam signed the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords" title="Paris Peace Accords">Paris Peace Accords</a>, ending U.S. involvement in the war.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> With the threat of U.S. retaliation gone, the North proceeded to violate the ceasefire and invaded the South with full military force. <a href="/wiki/Saigon" class="mw-redirect" title="Saigon">Saigon</a> was captured on 30 April 1975, and Vietnam was unified under Communist rule a year later, effectively bringing an end to one of the most unpopular wars of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">Cuban Missile Crisis</a> illustrates just how close to the brink of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">nuclear war</a> the world came during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, under <a href="/wiki/Fidel_Castro" title="Fidel Castro">Fidel Castro</a>'s socialist government, had formed close ties with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This was obviously disquieting to the United States, given Cuba's proximity. When <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_U-2" title="Lockheed U-2">Lockheed U-2</a> spy plane flights over the island revealed that Soviet missile launchers were being installed, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy" title="John F. Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> instituted a naval <a href="/wiki/Blockade" title="Blockade">blockade</a> and publicly confronted the Soviet Union. After a tense week, the Soviet Union backed down and ordered the launchers removed, not wanting to risk igniting a new world war.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_space_race">The space race</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: The space race"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Buzz_salutes_the_U.S._Flag.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Buzz_salutes_the_U.S._Flag.jpg/250px-Buzz_salutes_the_U.S._Flag.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="252" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Buzz_salutes_the_U.S._Flag.jpg/500px-Buzz_salutes_the_U.S._Flag.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3929" data-file-height="3967"></a><figcaption>In 1969, humans first set foot on <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">the Moon</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a></div>
<p>With <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> tensions running high, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and United States took their rivalry to the stars in 1957 with the Soviet launch of <a href="/wiki/Sputnik" class="mw-redirect" title="Sputnik">Sputnik</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A "space race" between the two powers followed.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The USSR reached several important milestones, such as the first craft on the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Luna_2" title="Luna 2">Luna 2</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the first human in space (<a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>).,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the first <a href="/wiki/Extravehicular_activity" title="Extravehicular activity">spacewalk</a> (<a href="/wiki/Alexey_Leonov" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexey Leonov">Alexey Leonov</a> on <a href="/wiki/Voskhod_2" title="Voskhod 2">Voskhod 2</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The U.S. pulled ahead eventually with its <a href="/wiki/Mercury_program" class="mw-redirect" title="Mercury program">Mercury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gemini_program" class="mw-redirect" title="Gemini program">Gemini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Apollo_program" title="Apollo program">Apollo</a> programs, which culminated in <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">Apollo 11</a> astronauts landing on the Moon on 20 July 1969.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Five more landings with astronauts followed (<a href="/wiki/Apollo_13" title="Apollo 13">Apollo 13</a> was forced to abort its mission).<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Nevertheless, despite its successes, the U.S. space program could not match many major achievements of the Soviet space program, such as <a href="/wiki/Lunokhod_program" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunokhod program">rover-based space exploration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venera_9" title="Venera 9">image and video transfer</a> from the surface of another planet, until the early 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In addition, both countries launched numerous <a href="/wiki/Space_probe" class="mw-redirect" title="Space probe">probes</a> into space, such as the <a href="/wiki/Venera_7" title="Venera 7">Venera 7</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Voyager_2" title="Voyager 2">Voyager 2</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In later decades, space became a somewhat friendlier place. Regular space flights with astronauts were made possible with the American <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a>, which was the first reusable spacecraft to be successfully used.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skylab" title="Skylab">Skylab</a> enabled prolonged human habitation in space.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the 1990s, work on the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a> began, and by the end of the century, while still incomplete, it was in continual use by astronauts from the United States, Europe, Russia, Japan, and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="The_end_of_the_Cold_War">The end of the Cold War</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: The end of the Cold War"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg/250px-West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg/500px-West_and_East_Germans_at_the_Brandenburg_Gate_in_1989.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="661" data-file-height="498"></a><figcaption>In 1989, the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> separating West and East Berlin fell.</figcaption></figure>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cold_War_(1985-1991)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cold War (1985-1991)">Cold War (1985-1991)</a></div>
<p>By the 1980s, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> was weakening. The <a href="/wiki/Sino-Soviet_split" title="Sino-Soviet split">Sino-Soviet split</a> had removed the USSR's most powerful ally, the People's Republic of China.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Arms_race" title="Arms race">arms race</a> with the U.S. was draining the country of funds, and further weakened by internal pressures, ethnic and political. <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, its last leader, attempted to reform the country with <i><a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Perestroika" title="Perestroika">perestroika</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but the formation of <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the fall of the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the breaking-off of several Soviet republics, such as <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> started a slippery slope of events that culminated in a coup to overthrow Gorbachev, organized by Communist Party hard-liners. <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a>, president of Russia, organized mass opposition, and the coup failed.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 26 December 1991, the Soviet Union was officially disbanded into its constituent republics, thus putting a final line under the already exhausted <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Information_and_communications_technology">Information and communications technology</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Information and communications technology"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Computer" title="Computer">Computer</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_computing_hardware" title="History of computing hardware">History of computing hardware</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a></div>
<p>The creation of the <a href="/wiki/Transistor" title="Transistor">transistor</a> revolutionized the development of the computer. The first computers, room-sized electro-mechanical devices built to break <a href="/wiki/Cryptographic" class="mw-redirect" title="Cryptographic">cryptographical</a> codes during World War II,<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> quickly became at least 20 times smaller using transistors.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Computers became <a href="/wiki/Computer_programming" title="Computer programming">reprogrammable</a> rather than fixed-purpose devices. The invention of <a href="/wiki/Programming_language" title="Programming language">programming languages</a> meant computer operators could concentrate on problem solving at a high-level, without having to think in terms of the individual instructions to the computer itself.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The creation of <a href="/wiki/Operating_systems" class="mw-redirect" title="Operating systems">operating systems</a> also vastly improved <a href="/wiki/Programming_productivity" title="Programming productivity">programming productivity</a>. Building on this, computer pioneers could now realize what they had envisioned. The <a href="/wiki/Graphical_user_interface" title="Graphical user interface">graphical user interface</a>, piloted by a <a href="/wiki/Computer_mouse" title="Computer mouse">computer mouse</a> made it simple to harness the power of the computer and made it more accessible to new users.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Computer_storage" class="mw-redirect" title="Computer storage">Storage</a> for computer programs progressed from <a href="/wiki/Punched_card" title="Punched card">punched cards</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paper_tape" class="mw-redirect" title="Paper tape">paper tape</a> to <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_tape" title="Magnetic tape">magnetic tape</a>, <a href="/wiki/Floppy_disk" title="Floppy disk">floppy disks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hard_disk" class="mw-redirect" title="Hard disk">hard disks</a>. <a href="/wiki/Core_memory" class="mw-redirect" title="Core memory">Core memory</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bubble_memory" title="Bubble memory">bubble memory</a> fell to <a href="/wiki/Random_access_memory" class="mw-redirect" title="Random access memory">random access memory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Colossus.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Colossus.jpg/250px-Colossus.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Colossus.jpg/500px-Colossus.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3504" data-file-height="2337"></a><figcaption>Colossus Mark 2 computer operated by <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Royal_Naval_Service" title="Women's Royal Naval Service">Wrens</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The invention of the <a href="/wiki/Word_processor" title="Word processor">word processor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spreadsheet" title="Spreadsheet">spreadsheet</a> and <a href="/wiki/Database" title="Database">database</a> greatly improved office productivity over the old paper, <a href="/wiki/Typewriter" title="Typewriter">typewriter</a> and filing cabinet methods.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The economic advantage given to businesses led to economic efficiencies in computers themselves. Cost-effective <a href="/wiki/Central_processing_unit" title="Central processing unit">CPUs</a> led to thousands of industrial and home-brew computer designs, many of which became successful; a home-computer boom was led by the <a href="/wiki/Apple_II" title="Apple II">Apple II</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sinclair_ZX80" class="mw-redirect" title="Sinclair ZX80">ZX80</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Commodore_PET" title="Commodore PET">Commodore PET</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, seeking to embrace the <a href="/wiki/Microcomputer_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Microcomputer revolution">microcomputer revolution</a>, devised its <a href="/wiki/IBM_Personal_Computer" title="IBM Personal Computer">IBM Personal Computer</a> (PC). Crucially, IBM developed the PC from third-party components that were available on the open market.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The only impediment to another company duplicating the system's architecture was the proprietary <a href="/wiki/BIOS" title="BIOS">BIOS</a> software. Other companies, starting with <a href="/wiki/Compaq" title="Compaq">Compaq</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reverse_engineered" class="mw-redirect" title="Reverse engineered">reverse engineered</a> the BIOS and released <a href="/wiki/PC_compatible" class="mw-redirect" title="PC compatible">PC compatible</a> computers that soon became the dominant architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">Microsoft</a>, which produced an operating system for the PC, rode this wave of popularity to become the world's leading software company.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The 1980s heralded the <a href="/wiki/Information_Age" title="Information Age">Information Age</a>. The rise of computer applications and <a href="/wiki/Data_processing" title="Data processing">data processing</a> made ethereal "information" as valuable as physical commodities. This brought about new concerns surrounding intellectual property issues. The U.S. Government made algorithms patentable, forming the basis of <a href="/wiki/Software_patent" title="Software patent">software patents</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The controversy over these and <a href="/wiki/Proprietary_software" title="Proprietary software">proprietary software</a> led <a href="/wiki/Richard_Stallman" title="Richard Stallman">Richard Stallman</a> to create the <a href="/wiki/Free_Software_Foundation" title="Free Software Foundation">Free Software Foundation</a> and begin the <a href="/wiki/GNU" title="GNU">GNU Project</a>, paving the way for a <a href="/wiki/Free_software_movement" title="Free software movement">free software movement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Computers also became a usable platform for entertainment. Computer games were first developed by software programmers exercising their creativity on large systems at universities, but these efforts became commercially successful in <a href="/wiki/Arcade_game" title="Arcade game">arcade games</a> such as <i><a href="/wiki/Pong" title="Pong">Pong</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Space_Invaders" title="Space Invaders">Space Invaders</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Once the home computer market was established, young programmers in their bedrooms became the core of a youthful <a href="/wiki/Video_game_industry" title="Video game industry">video game industry</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In order to take advantage of advancing technology, <a href="/wiki/Games_console" class="mw-redirect" title="Games console">games consoles</a> were created. Like arcade systems, these machines had custom hardware designed to do game-oriented operations (such as <a href="/wiki/Sprite_(computer_science)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sprite (computer science)">sprites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parallax_scrolling" title="Parallax scrolling">parallax scrolling</a>) in preference to general purpose computing tasks.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:IBM_PC_5150.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/IBM_PC_5150.jpg/250px-IBM_PC_5150.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="184" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/IBM_PC_5150.jpg/500px-IBM_PC_5150.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="962" data-file-height="708"></a><figcaption>The first model of the <a href="/wiki/IBM_PC" class="mw-redirect" title="IBM PC">IBM PC</a>, the personal computer whose successors would fill the world.</figcaption></figure><p><a href="/wiki/Computer_network" title="Computer network">Computer networks</a> appeared in two main styles; the <a href="/wiki/Local_area_network" title="Local area network">local area network</a>, linking computers in an office or school to each other, and the <a href="/wiki/Wide_area_network" title="Wide area network">wide area network</a>, linking the local area networks together. Initially, computers depended on the <a href="/wiki/PSTN" class="mw-redirect" title="PSTN">telephone networks</a> to link to each other, spawning the <a href="/wiki/Bulletin_board_system" title="Bulletin board system">Bulletin Board</a> sub-culture.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, a <a href="/wiki/DARPA" title="DARPA">DARPA</a> project to create bomb-proof computer networks led to the creation of the Internet, a network of networks. The core of this network was the robust <a href="/wiki/TCP/IP" class="mw-redirect" title="TCP/IP">TCP/IP</a> <a href="/wiki/Network_protocol" class="mw-redirect" title="Network protocol">network protocol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Thanks to efforts from <a href="/wiki/Al_Gore" title="Al Gore">Al Gore</a>, the Internet grew beyond its military role when universities and commercial businesses were permitted to connect their networks to it.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The main impetus for this was <a href="/wiki/Electronic_mail" class="mw-redirect" title="Electronic mail">electronic mail</a>, a far faster and convenient form of communication than a conventional letter and memo distribution, and the <a href="/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol" title="File Transfer Protocol">File Transfer Protocol</a> (FTP). However, the Internet remained largely unknown to the general public, who were used to Bulletin Boards and services like <a href="/wiki/Compuserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Compuserve">Compuserve</a> and <a href="/wiki/AOL" title="AOL">America Online</a>. This changed when <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a> devised a simpler form of <a href="/wiki/Vannevar_Bush" title="Vannevar Bush">Vannevar Bush</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Hypertext" title="Hypertext">hypertext</a>, which he dubbed the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">World Wide Web</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> "The Web" suddenly changed the Internet into a printing press beyond the geographic boundaries of physical countries; it was termed "<a href="/wiki/Cyberspace" title="Cyberspace">cyberspace</a>". Anyone with a computer and an Internet connection could write pages in the simple <a href="/wiki/HTML" title="HTML">HTML</a> format and publish their thoughts to the world.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Web's immense success also fueled the commercial use of the Internet. Convenient home shopping had been an element of "visions of the future" since the development of the telephone, but now the race was on to provide convenient, interactive consumerism.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Companies trading through websites became known as "<a href="/wiki/Dot_com_company" class="mw-redirect" title="Dot com company">dot coms</a>", due to the ".com" suffix of commercial Internet addresses.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The change of the century also lead to the fear and paranoia of <a href="/wiki/Year_2000_problem" title="Year 2000 problem">Y2K</a>, where it was hypothesized that the World's computers would glitch and cause havoc on banks, prisons, transit systems and more.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="The_world_at_the_end_of_the_century">The world at the end of the century</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Key_events_of_the_20th_century&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: The world at the end of the century"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1990s" title="1990s">1990s</a></div>
<p>By the end of the century, more technological advances and scientific discoveries had been made than in all of preceding history. Humans <a href="/wiki/Dolly_(sheep)" title="Dolly (sheep)">now had the ability</a> to <a href="/wiki/Cloning" title="Cloning">clone</a> organisms and were able to <a href="/wiki/Gene_mapping" title="Gene mapping">map</a> and <a href="/wiki/DNA_sequencing" title="DNA sequencing">sequence</a> the entire <a href="/wiki/Human_genome" title="Human genome">human genome</a><sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> in the world's largest collaborative biological project.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Communications and information technology, transportation technology, and medical advances have radically altered daily lives. Europe appeared to be at a sustainable peace for the first time in recorded history. The people of the Indian subcontinent, a sixth of the world population at the end of the century, had attained indigenous independence for the first time in centuries. China, an ancient nation comprising a fifth of the world's population, was finally open to the world in a new and powerful synthesis of West and East, creating a new state after the near-complete destruction of the old cultural order.  With the end of colonialism and the Cold War, nearly a billion people in Africa were left with truly independent new nation-states, some cut from whole cloth, standing up after centuries of foreign domination.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg/330px-Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="204" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg/500px-Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Global_Warming_Predictions_Map.jpg 2x" data-file-width="559" data-file-height="408"></a><figcaption>The geographic distribution of surface warming during the 21st century calculated by the <a href="/wiki/HadCM3" title="HadCM3">HadCM3</a> climate model if a business as usual scenario is assumed for economic growth and greenhouse gas emissions. In this figure, the globally averaged warming corresponds to 3.0&nbsp;°C (5.4&nbsp;°F).</figcaption></figure>
<p>The world was undergoing its second major period of <a href="/wiki/Globalization" title="Globalization">globalization</a>; <a href="/wiki/First_globalization" title="First globalization">the first</a>, which started in the 19th century, having been terminated by World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since the US was in a position of almost unchallenged domination, a major part of the process was <a href="/wiki/Americanization" title="Americanization">Americanization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This led to anti-Western and <a href="/wiki/Anti-Americanism" title="Anti-Americanism">anti-American</a> feelings in parts of the world, especially the Middle East.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The influence of China and India was also rising, as the world's largest populations, long marginalized by the West and by their rulers, were rapidly integrating with the world economy.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>However, several problems face the world. The gap between rich and poor nations continued to widen. Some said that this problem could not be fixed, that there was a set amount of wealth and it could only be shared by so many. Others said that the powerful nations with large economies were not doing enough to help improve the rapidly evolving economies of the <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">Third World</a>. However, developing countries faced many challenges, including the scale of the task to be surmounted, rapidly growing populations, and the need to protect the environment and the cost that goes along with it. Meanwhile in <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a>, the apartheid came to an end and <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> became the nation's first black president, leading to the formation of a new democratic government, after having been ruled for four and a half decades of systemised racial segregation. In <a href="/wiki/Rwanda" title="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, an estimated one million people were massacred in the <a href="/wiki/Rwandan_genocide" title="Rwandan genocide">genocide</a>, which included targets of <a href="/wiki/Tutsi" title="Tutsi">Tutsis</a> and moderate <a href="/wiki/Hutu" title="Hutu">Hutu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Twa_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Twa people">Twa people</a>.
</p><p>Terrorism rose in the late century; the <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma_City_bombing" title="Oklahoma City bombing">Oklahoma City bombing</a> killed 168. Dictatorship and the spread of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons</a> were other issues requiring attention. The world was still blighted by small-scale wars and other violent conflicts, fueled by competition over resources and ethnic conflicts. <a href="/wiki/Despotism" title="Despotism">Despots</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" class="mw-redirect" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> of <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> continued to lead their nations toward the development of nuclear weapons.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Disease threatened to destabilize many regions of the world. New viruses such as <a href="/wiki/SARS" title="SARS">SARS</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Nile_virus" title="West Nile virus">West Nile</a> continued to spread.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In poor nations, <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a> and other diseases affected the majority of the population. Millions were infected with HIV, the virus which causes AIDS. The virus was becoming an <a href="/wiki/AIDS_in_Africa" class="mw-redirect" title="AIDS in Africa">epidemic in southern Africa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Usage of <a href="/wiki/Penicillin" title="Penicillin">penicillin</a> became widespread to combat bacterial infections worldwide.
</p><p>Perhaps most importantly, it was speculated that in the long term, environmental problems threatened the planet's livability. The most serious problem was <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" class="mw-redirect" title="Global warming">global warming</a>, which was predicted to frequently flood coastal areas, due to human-caused emission of <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> produced by the burning of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a>. Like the threat of a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warfare" title="Nuclear warfare">nuclear world war</a>, the shift of <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> has since <a href="/wiki/Damocles" class="mw-redirect" title="Damocles">added to the fear</a> of the possibility of <a href="/wiki/Human_extinction" title="Human extinction">human extinction</a>, although not overnight but over several decades.<sup id="cite_ref-Rich_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rich-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This prompted many nations to negotiate and sign the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_Protocol" title="Kyoto Protocol">Kyoto treaty</a>, which set mandatory limits on carbon dioxide emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Millennium_celebrations" title="Millennium celebrations">celebration of the 20th century’s ending</a> expressed the popular opinion that <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve" title="New Year's Eve">New Year's Eve</a> 1999 and <a href="/wiki/New_Year%27s_Day" title="New Year's Day">New Year's Day</a> 2000 marked the <a href="/wiki/Millennium#Debate_over_millennium_celebrations" title="Millennium">turn of the millennium</a>, while strictly speaking the 20th century ended on New Year's Eve 2000 and the 21st century began on New Year's Day 2001.
</p>

<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFMason2018" class="citation web cs1">Mason, Amanda (9 January 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iwm.org.uk/history/the-u-boat-campaign-that-almost-broke-britain">"The U-Boat Campaign That Almost Broke Britain"</a>. <i>Imperial War Museums</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/chemical-weapons-warfare-remembrance-day-poison-mustard-gas-first-world-war-ypres-isis-a7005416.html">"Remembering the day the first poison gas attack changed the face of warfare forever"</a>. <i>The Independent</i>. 28 April 2016<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">11 December</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Independent&amp;rft.atitle=Remembering+the+day+the+first+poison+gas+attack+changed+the+face+of+warfare+forever&amp;rft.date=2016-04-28&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.co.uk%2Fnews%2Fworld%2Fpolitics%2Fchemical-weapons-warfare-remembrance-day-poison-mustard-gas-first-world-war-ypres-isis-a7005416.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKey+events+of+the+20th+century" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFBrosnan2018" class="citation web cs1">Brosnan, Matt (8 January 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.iwm.org.uk/history/how-britain-invented-the-tank-in-the-first-world-war">"How Britain Invented The Tank in the First World War"</a>. <i>Imperial War Museums</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.shmoop.com/great-depression/politics.html">"Politics in The Great Depression"</a>. <i>shmoop.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFCostello1982" class="citation book cs1">Costello, John (1 December 1982). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fL1JXhq4VwMC"><i>The Pacific War: 1941–1945</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-119" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFBurrell2004" class="citation journal cs1">Burrell, Robert S. </li>
<li id="cite_note-136"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-136" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.holocaust.cz/en/history/final-solution/general-2/mass-deportations-to-the-concentration-and-extermination-camps/">"Mass deportations to the concentration and extermination camps | Holocaust"</a>. <i>holocaust.cz</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-184"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-184" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFMahmud2010" class="citation journal cs1">Mahmud, Tayyab (28 April 2010). </li>
<li id="cite_note-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-185" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFHyde2016" class="citation web cs1">Hyde, Tim (13 July 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.aeaweb.org/research/are-colonial-era-borders-holding-africa-back">"Are colonial-era borders drawn by Europeans holding Africa back?"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/American_Economic_Association" title="American Economic Association">American Economic Association</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-200"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-200" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFHastings1987" class="citation book cs1">Hastings, Max (1987). <span class="id-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/koreanwar00hast"><i>Korean War</i></a></span>. </li>
<li id="cite_note-201"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-201" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFCumings2010" class="citation book cs1">Cumings, Bruce (2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lY5-7ZirsmgC"><i>The Korean War: A History</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFBonnell2018" class="citation web cs1">Bonnell, Andrew (3 October 2018). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://theconversation.com/world-politics-explainer-the-fall-of-the-berlin-wall-100812">"World politics explainer: The fall of the Berlin Wall"</a>. <i>The Conversation</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-264"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-264" aria-label="Jump up" title="Jump up">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1238218222"><cite id="CITEREFLukacs1993" class="citation book cs1">Lukacs, John (1993). <span class="id-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/endoftwentiethce00luka"><i>The end of the twentieth century and the end of the modern age</i></a></span>. Ticknor &amp; Fields. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780395584729" title="Special:BookSources/9780395584729"><bdi>9780395584729</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+end+of+the+twentieth+century+and+the+end+of+the+modern+age&amp;rft.pub=Ticknor+%26+Fields&amp;rft.date=1993&amp;rft.isbn=9780395584729&amp;rft.aulast=Lukacs&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fendoftwentiethce00luka&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AKey+events+of+the+20th+century" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
